title: How many battle deaths will ACLED record in Sudan in August 2017?
preds: Monthly average in 2017 has been about 99 battle fatalities. In terms of seasonality, August and October have been the lowest for battle fatalities in Sudan (looking at the past ten years).  Based on that would rule out top two options.  There have not been fewer than 7 fatalities in an given month since November 2011 so ruling out lowest option.  Based on seasonality will probably be lower than July (63) and June (47) so leaning toward the second option.
Swayed by the reputation of @Dsarin. What the heck, only one day left.

Guterres has named a newp Deputy Dir. of S. Sudan mission, which could help influence reduced battle deaths, as could visit of USAID boss Mark Green to Sudan. I am at low end of 122 to 321, but sense it could inch above 121.
per the real time data, 27 deaths have been recorded for August so far. 239 were recorded in July, 142 in June, and 418 in May. Three months' average is 296,
Following @JS as he is an expert in forecasting such events.
Changing to match the average of the crowd. Dropping out of this one
note to self: focus on another question where the end date is a bit further away. This forecast was made 1 week before closing date
Well, it's a pity that ACLED has no updates for August.
Battle relared deaths in Sudan, according to the ACLED data appear to be running at about 14-15 per month on average for 2017.  My prediction is a simple extrapolation of this figure into August

Multiple open sources note that divisive but determined "rebel groups" are seeking help from neighbor regimes or other proxy actors which could cause a "surge" over next few months. Acled reported 10 events and 76 fatals during May.

The Realtime 2017 All Africa File spreadsheet now has data up to and including August 7th.  There have been six incidents that meet the above criteria and all were within the Battle-No change of territory category.  There have been 25 fatalities up to and including August 7th.  The notes related to the incidents describe mostly small scale militia and tribal clashes.  The sources were Radio Dabanga, Sudan Tribune, Radio Tamazuj and UNAMID.  Four of the six incidents were in the Darfur region of Sudan.  Please credit my girlfriend's excel skills.  That was a tough one to filter out.

I am taking into account not only the history of the number of fatalities in August over a several year period, but also the 3 month extension of the Unilateral Ceasefire announced by Sudanese President Omer al-Bashir announced in July 2017 (1). While there is always the likelihood of another bloody outbreak of violence, I believe the Sudan Government's desire for the removal of the 20 year trade embargo with the United States plays a key role in the decrease in fatalities recorded.   1. http://af.reuters.com/article/topNews/idAFKBN19O0K2-OZATP

690 deaths until August 5th for the whole of 2017 (=217 days) -> 3,17 deaths per day
If violence would always have been at the same level and if it would stay this way, this would lead to 82 deaths in the remaining days of August. While this assumption might provide a reasonable starting point, this wasn't the case. Almost half of all recorded deaths occured in May. Jan 16
Feb 76
March 24
April 121
May 343
June 47
July 63 Of the 343 deaths that occured in May, 229 occured in clashes between government forces supported by RSF militia and SLA-MM supported by SLA-Transitional Council forces (a splinter faction of SLA-AW) on 20 May in Musbat and Wadi Howar of North Darfur. If we assume that such a battle is an exception and won't occur in August, it might be reasonable to only count 114 deaths in May, which would lead to an average of  2,12 deaths per day. For the remaining of August, this would mean that 55 deaths could be expected. I won't put too much weight on that number, because there might be big fluctuation. There are no fixed battlelines and an abundance of possible actors. 49 of the 64 deaths in July, for example, died in only two days of clashes between the Ma’alia and Rizeigat tribes in El Mejlid and Donki Umarag. Tribal violence is hard to predict. If that clash hadn't occured, there might have only been 15 deaths in July. At the same time, it is easily imaginable that another tribal clash  or fighting between the gov. and rebels might have occured, raising the number to those of April. Meaning: This question is hard to forecast. "Less than 7" however never occured during 2017. "More than 321" only once in May and with some rare big-scale fighting. Both categories seem unlikely to me during August. -> 0% and 1%  "More than 122" also only occured in May, though April obv. came close. ->5% According to the above mentioned numbers and their average, the middle box might seem as the safest bet, but June & July very pretty close to be under 46 and if it weren't for above mentioned tribal clashes, July would have been way under the treshhold.  Due to lack of better knowledge, I therefore distribute the remaining percentages equally and wait for the next ACLED update.

Since there were no recorded deaths in August given the deaths took place in Sudan under the event type constraint, the most likely number would be under 7 (probably 0). However, I found 4 deaths each between 7 and 46 as well as between 46 and 122 thereby spitballing 2% each for both.
(I initially forecast September instead of August - methodology roughly the same, results slightly different since historically August has been a less violent month).
Conflict has been 200 fatalities a month. Likely to continue.

They data are lumpy, so I did a lot of blending of different sections (September 2014-2016, All Months 2014-2017, Pace Year 2008 and Pace Month May 2014 - 2017) and applied some basic statistics and blended again to smooth. Although the current year looks quieter than the proceeding years, volatility linked to exogenous forces is difficult to factor into the equation. From a quick news scan, tension seem to be low; if i included the current mood in this forecast, i would probably revise down the number of deaths and increase the share in the 46 to 122 bucket.
Since the prediction request specifically states SUDAN and not SOUTH SUDAN, the search results in a range from 12 to 24 over the last few months. I expect it to stay under 50 for August.
The monthly data seems to suggest that <7 & >321 are unlikely. My estimate is that the number for August will most likely follow the trend.
South Sudan violence shows no signs of abating
As of today, there are no cases for the a required event type.   Will review data on download dates.

just looking at existing data & also at recent news sources around the area, which are fairly spotty. Most news focuses on recent tribal matters, which seem outside the purview of the question, such as http://www.sudantribune.com/spip.php?article63055
After peaking in May (343), this category of deaths dropped to 47 in June and 63 in July. Trying to find recent news of the situation and will update forecast when/if relevant news located.
Probabilities are based on the data for the first seven months of the year.
Monthly battle fatalities per month this year from the ACLED spreadsheet online at http://www.acleddata.com/data/realtime-data/:  16, 76, 24, 121, 343, 47, 63.

Violence among farmers and herders are likely to continue at about the same level. The decision to cut UNAMID funding will probably not show any effect on the amount of violence until next year. One thing that could change this is if the Sudanese government decides to make a push to ensure control in Darfur.
Rebalancing my answer because I realized I should have switched my original 50 and 40.
July 2017 fatalities noted at 63, June was 47.   Think this trend will hold.

The average number of deaths in a given month this year has been 99 and in only one month has the death toll exceeded 321 and in only two has it dropped below 46. I suspect we see around 100 or more deaths this month in the country.
Based on general news and GJP consensus.
consistent with long term monthly history

Considering ACLED 2015, 2016 (even) yearly trends and 2017 monthly ACLED numbers, linearly estimating from those numbers and "Bell curve" distributing likelihood among 3 reasonable options. Extremely low or high numbers are extremely unlikely and uncharacteristic of the past records. However a token count is given to the upper limit as in active war zones events with extreme number of victims can't ever be completely discounted.

This is an estimated probability distribution based on the ACLED All-Africa file. 2017 has been much more violent than 2016. Most of the fatalities are in the tails of the distribution. Of 16 incidents in the data set that produced more than 10 fatalities (just above the standard deviation of 7.05), 12 (75%) were battles. So basically this question comes down to how many battles take place this month.
Deaths will probably stick closely to trend.
Based on an average 137 deaths per month this year

Working under the assumption that violence is going to continue being lower than 2016. Used monthly averages, but reduced may (343) which was an outlier. Will adjust ratings closer to the end of the prediction by adding ACLED data. As of 7 August there have been no reported fatalities in the ACLED data.

It looks like there were about 10 battle related deaths in July, and news reports showed a death toll of 25 in recent fighting, but that a UN peacekeeping force just arrived. So my reasoning is that with the already at least 25 incidents, plus last month's total would be most likely.
15 fatalities YTD, spread over 6 incidents. Biggest incident in late June (7 fatalities).
Based on existing figures for last year, no change at political level.

Already 38 lives have been lost from Monday and Tuesday.
http://aa.com.tr/en/africa/tribal-clashes-in-south-sudan-claim-38-lives/880936
Will new arrival of UN troops quell the killings?
http://www.un.org/apps/news/story.asp?NewsID=57323#.WYvib7FMGf0
Flare ups mostly, but one can never discount a market bombing with many casualties.
Not hearing very much about the conflict currently; summer temperatures may preclude heavy military action
It looks like there are periodic hot conflicts between groups resulting battle deaths exceeding 10.
Based on ACLED stats for SSudan in 7/2017
